prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Continuum observations requested. Band 6 is selected as it yields the optimum S/N distribution based on our predictions.
The requested angular resolution is chosen to ensure our targets will be unresolved by ALMA maximising their S/N.

Our predictions for the ALMA fluxes of each individual source are based on observations their UV luminosity and continuum slope.
The observed UV continuum slope (beta) is theoretically expected and empirically demonstrated [using stacking at z~1.5-3.0, e.g. Heinis+2013; Coppin+2014)] to correlate with the observed ratio of the total IR to UV luminosity.
Instead of relying on previous observations we develop a theoretical framework from which we can obtain predictions for the IRX-beta relationship. Within this framework we can vary any of the assumptions.
The first step in this framework is to specify an intrinsic SED. We do this using the PEGASE.2 stellar population synthesis model and assume 100 Myr previous constant star formation, Z=0.004 stellar metallicity, and escape fraction of 0.0. These parameters are chosen conservatively based on predictions from large hydro-dynamical models of galaxy formation. Reducing the metallicity or duration of previous star formation, or increasing the escape fraction, will result in enhanced predictions for the obs sub-mm/mm flux. This intrinsic SED is shown in Fig. 2.
We then include dust using a choice of E(B-V) (or A_V) and dust curve. Using an energy balance approach we can then estimate the IR luminosity. By then assuming an IR template [in this case we assume a greybody + NIR power-law (e.g. Casey+2013) with T=30K, emissivity=1.5, and alpha=2.0] we can predict the rest-frame IR SED and how it changes with increasing dust attenuation. An exmaple SED created using this model is shown in Fig. 2.
From this "total" SED we can derive a relationship between the observed UV continuum slope and the ratio of the rest-frame UV flux (i.e. the observed NIR flux) and the expected ALMA flux (see Fig. 4). For each individual source, we can then predict its expected ALMA flux.
This relationship is sensitive to the entire range of assumptions, however it is particularly sensitive to the choice of dust curve. Assuming an SMC-like curve yields rest-frame IR fluxes (for a given UV continuum slope and flux) which are typically ~4-5 times lower than assuming a Calzetti+2000 curve.
Assuming a Calzetti+2000 curve (which is favoured by stacking results at z~3) we obtain a median S/N for the sample of ~15. If instead we assume an SMC like curve (Pei+92) the median S/N falls to 3. The full signal-to-noise distribution is shown in Fig. 4.
Our choice of sensitivity is motivated by the desire to constrain the IRX-beta relationship independent of the the dust curve. While some objects are expected to be detected at only low-S/N (esp. if the dust curve is similar to SMC) our predictions demonstrate we can still robustly characterise the IRX-beta relationship.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Thanks largely to the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) it is now possible to identify large numbers of rest-frame UV selected Lyman-break galaxies (LBGs) to z~8, well within the epoch of reionisation. The large numbers of sources now available allow us to characterise the rest-frame UV luminosity function and thus constrain the star formation activity in the Universe during this critical period its history. However, HST probes only the rest-frame UV and thus can only be used to constrain the unobscured star formation activity potentially missing the bulk of activity even at z~7. To overcome this limitation we propose to use obtain ALMA observations of 20 typical ~L* LBGs at z~6-7. These observations will allow us to place the first robust constraints on the obscured star formation activity in the first billion years. These observations will also allow us to place meaningful constraints on the IRX-beta relation at these redshifts allowing us to estimate the obscured star formation activity in faint systems otherwise inaccessible to ALMA at z~7 and beyond.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
